comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: This picture of South Steyne is hard to date because some of her age-related features are hidden. I see that the ferry directly under the bridge still has her tall steamer funnel. When new in 1938, and after wartime camouflage drab was removed in 1946, South Steyne's steel promenade deckhouse sides (upper deck) were painted a darkish brown to mimic the varnished teak of her doors and appear so in this picture. That colour became white with yellow/cream at window level in the mid 1950's and stayed that way to today. This picture is most likely c1950.

comment.author: 90993042@N04
comment._content: an interesting aside.....www.trove.nla.gov .au/    on Oct 3 1938 reports...."Captain RM Beedle and Mr G. Mackenzie ( chief engineer ), are returning to Great Britain, after bringing the new Manly ferry South Steyne to Sydney."

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: Yes Waterlooian, Pedder and Mylchreest Ltd of London were contracted to bring South Steyne to Sydney. A decade earlier, when the Manly ferry Dee Why was brought from near Glasgow to Sydney, there was almost a mutiny onboard over conditions and payment.
